clipboardHistory.value:
# output=<not set>
font=JetBrainsMono:size=14
dpi-aware=no
# use-bold=no
prompt="❯  "
# placeholder=
# icon-theme=hicolor
# icons-enabled=yes
# fields=filename,name,generic
# password-character=*
# filter-desktop=no
# match-mode=fzf
# sort-result=yes
# match-counter=no
# delayed-filter-ms=300
# delayed-filter-limit=20000
# show-actions=no
terminal=footclient -e
# launch-prefix=<not set>
# list-executables-in-path=no

# anchor=center
# x-margin=0
# y-margin=0
lines=16
width=50
tabs=4
horizontal-pad=50
vertical-pad=18
inner-pad=10

image-size-ratio=.25

# line-height=<use font metrics>
# letter-spacing=0

# layer=overlay
exit-on-keyboard-focus-loss=no

# cache=<not set>

# render-workers=<number of logical CPUs>
# match-workers=<number of logical CPUs>

[colors]
background=2e3440dd
text=eceff4ff
prompt=81a1c1ff
placeholder=81a1c1ff
input=81a1c1ff
match=88c0d0ff
selection-match=88c0d0ff
selection=4c566add
selection-text=eceff4ff
# counter=93a1a1ff
border=81a1c1ff

[border]
# width=1
# radius=10

[dmenu]
# mode=text  # text|index
# exit-immediately-if-empty=no

[key-bindings]
# cancel=Escape Control+g Control+c Control+bracketleft
# execute=Return KP_Enter Control+y
# execute-or-next=Tab
# execute-input=Shift+Return Shift+KP_Enter
# cursor-left=Left Control+b
# cursor-left-word=Control+Left Mod1+b
# cursor-right=Right Control+f
# cursor-right-word=Control+Right Mod1+f
# cursor-home=Home Control+a
# cursor-end=End Control+e
# delete-prev=BackSpace Control+h
# delete-prev-word=Mod1+BackSpace Control+BackSpace Control+w
# delete-line-backward=Control+u
# delete-next=Delete KP_Delete Control+d
# delete-next-word=Mod1+d Control+Delete Control+KP_Delete
# delete-line-forward=Control+k
# prev=Up Control+p
# prev-with-wrap=ISO_Left_Tab
# prev-page=Page_Up KP_Page_Up
# next=Down Control+n
# next-with-wrap=none
# next-page=Page_Down KP_Page_Down
# expunge=Shift+Delete
# clipboard-paste=Control+v XF86Paste
# primary-paste=Shift+Insert Shift+KP_Insert

# custom-N: *dmenu mode only*. Like execute, but with a non-zero
# exit-code; custom-1 exits with code 10, custom-2 with 11, custom-3
# with 12, and so on.

# custom-1=Mod1+1
# custom-2=Mod1+2
# custom-3=Mod1+3
# custom-4=Mod1+4

# custom-7=Mod1+7

# custom-13=Mod1+numbersign
# custom-14=Mod1+dollar

# custom-16=Mod1+dead_circumflex

#!/bin/bash

grim -g "$(swaymsg -t get_tree | jq -r '.. | select(.pid? and .visible?) | .rect | "\(.x),\(.y) \(.width)x\(.height)"' | slurp)" - | swappy -f -

#!/bin/bash

SELECTION="$(printf "󰌾 Lock\n󰤄 Suspend\n󰍃 Log out\n Reboot\n Reboot to UEFI\n󰐥 Shutdown" | fuzzel --dmenu -l 6 -w 18 -p "Select an option: ")"

confirm_action() {
    local action="$1"
    CONFIRMATION="$(printf "No\nYes" | fuzzel --dmenu -l 2 -w 18 -p "$action?")"
    [[ "$CONFIRMATION" == *"Yes"* ]]
}

case $SELECTION in
    *"󰌾 Lock"*)
        gtklock;;
    *"󰤄 Suspend"*)
        if confirm_action "Suspend"; then
            systemctl suspend
        fi;;
    *"󰍃 Log out"*)
        if confirm_action "Log out"; then
            swaymsg exit
        fi;;
    *" Reboot"*)
        if confirm_action "Reboot"; then
            systemctl reboot
        fi;;
    *" Reboot to UEFI"*)
        if confirm_action "Reboot to UEFI"; then
            systemctl reboot --firmware-setup
        fi;;
    *"󰐥 Shutdown"*)
        if confirm_action "Shutdown"; then
            systemctl poweroff
        fi;;
esac

#!/bin/bash

##
## By default, Sway sets HiDPI displays to 2.0 scaling. Testing revealed this
## can lead to a bad experience in the live environment on some displays. This
## script checks if the scaling has been set to 2.0, and sets it to 1.5 instead.
##
## After configuring your outputs according to your preference in
## ~/.config/sway/config.d/output, this script can be deleted.
##

# Iterate over each output and check for 2.0 scaling
swaymsg -t get_outputs | jq -r '.[] | select(.scale == 2.0) | .name' | while read -r output; do
	# Set scale factor to 1.5 for HiDPI displays
	swaymsg output "$output" scale 1.5
done

#!/bin/bash

# Send a notification about the keybinding cheatsheet
notify-send -t 600000 -i $HOME/.icons/up-left.png "  Click the keyboard icon in the Waybar to launch the Sway keybinding cheatsheet."

# Self-destructing script!
rm $HOME/.config/sway/config.d/cheatsheet_hint
rm -- "$0"

#!/bin/bash

if bluetoothctl show | grep 'Powered: no' -q; then
    bluetoothctl power on
else
    bluetoothctl power off
fi

#!/bin/bash

# Check what workspace we are on
current_workspace=$(swaymsg -t get_workspaces | jq '.[] | select(.focused == true).num')

# Check the total number of workspaces
total_workspaces=$(swaymsg -t get_workspaces | jq 'length')

# Check if the current workspace is greater than or equal to the total number of workspaces
if [ "$current_workspace" -ge "$total_workspaces" ]; then
    # If it is, create a new workspace at current_workspace + 1
    swaymsg workspace number "$((current_workspace + 1))"
else
    # If it's not, simply switch to the next workspace
    swaymsg workspace next
fi

#!/bin/sh

# usage: import-gsettings
config="${XDG_CONFIG_HOME:-$HOME/.config}/gtk-3.0/settings.ini"
if [ ! -f "$config" ]; then exit 1; fi

gnome_schema="org.gnome.desktop.interface"
gtk_theme="$(grep 'gtk-theme-name' "$config" | cut -d'=' -f2)"
icon_theme="$(grep 'gtk-icon-theme-name' "$config" | cut -d'=' -f2)"
cursor_theme="$(grep 'gtk-cursor-theme-name' "$config" | cut -d'=' -f2)"
font_name="$(grep 'gtk-font-name' "$config" | cut -d'=' -f2)"
gsettings set "$gnome_schema" gtk-theme "$gtk_theme"
gsettings set "$gnome_schema" icon-theme "$icon_theme"
gsettings set "$gnome_schema" cursor-theme "$cursor_theme"
gsettings set "$gnome_schema" font-name "$font_name"

# Run the cheatsheet notification script

exec ~/.config/sway/scripts/cheatsheet_hint.sh

# Auth with polkit-gnome:
exec /usr/lib/polkit-gnome/polkit-gnome-authentication-agent-1

# Import environment variables for user systemd service manager
exec systemctl --user import-environment DISPLAY WAYLAND_DISPLAY SWAYSOCK XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP

# Update dbus environments with display variables
exec hash dbus-update-activation-environment 2>/dev/null && \
    dbus-update-activation-environment --systemd DISPLAY WAYLAND_DISPLAY SWAYSOCK XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP=sway

# Idle configuration
exec swayidle idlehint 1
exec_always swayidle -w before-sleep "gtklock -d"

# Desktop notifications
exec mako

# Start foot server
exec_always --no-startup-id foot --server

# Autotiling
exec autotiling

# Launch all Sway applications in autostart directories
exec dex -a -e sway

# cliphist
exec wl-paste --type text --watch cliphist store
exec wl-paste --type image --watch cliphist store

# Outputs
exec kanshi

# nwg-drawer
exec_always nwg-drawer -r -c 7 -is 90 -mb 10 -ml 50 -mr 50 -mt 10

# swayrd
exec_always swayrd

# Sway Fader
exec python3 ~/.config/sway/scripts/swayfader.py

local function Spectrum()
  vim.cmd.colorscheme("tokyonight-storm")

  -- Custom Colours
  vim.cmd([[highlight LineNr guifg=#29465B]])
  vim.cmd([[highlight CursorColumn guifg=#737CA1]])
  vim.cmd([[highlight CursorLineNr guifg=#FF00FF]])
  vim.cmd([[highlight IncSearch guibg=#FF00FF]])
end

Spectrum()

vim.cmd("colorscheme tokyonight-storm")

    -- Custom Colours
    vim.cmd([[highlight LineNr guifg=#29465B]])
    vim.cmd([[highlight CursorColumn guifg=#737CA1]])
    vim.cmd([[highlight CursorLineNr guifg=#FF00FF]])
    vim.cmd([[highlight IncSearch guibg=#FF00FF]])

local state = {
	buf = -1, -- The one and only shared terminal buffer
	floating = { win = -1 },
	vertical = { win = -1 },
	horizontal = { win = -1 },
	last_mode = nil,
}

-- This function now correctly ensures the shared buffer exists
local function set_shared_buffer()
	if not vim.api.nvim_buf_is_valid(state.buf) then
		state.buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true) -- Create if it doesn't exist
	end
	return state.buf
end

local function create_floating_window(opts)
	opts = opts or {}
	local width = opts.width or math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.75)
	local height = opts.height or math.floor(vim.o.lines * 0.75)

	local col = math.floor((vim.o.columns - width) / 2)
	local row = math.floor((vim.o.lines - height) / 2)

	local buf = set_shared_buffer() -- Use the shared buffer

	local win_config = {
		relative = "editor",
		width = width,
		height = height,
		col = col,
		row = row,
		style = "minimal",
		border = "rounded",
	}

	local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, win_config)
	state.floating.win = win -- Store the created window ID
	return win -- Return the window ID directly
end

local function create_split_window(orientation)
	local cmd = orientation == "vertical" and "vsplit" or "split"
	vim.cmd(cmd) -- This creates a new window displaying the *current* buffer initially

	local buf = set_shared_buffer() -- Use the shared buffer
	vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(0, buf) -- Set the new split to display the shared buffer

	if orientation == "horizontal" then
		vim.cmd("resize 10")
	end

	local win = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
	state[orientation].win = win -- Store the created window ID
	return win
end

-- Helper to check if our shared terminal is active in a given window
local function is_our_terminal_visible(win_id)
	if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_id) then
		local win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_id)
		-- Check if it's our shared buffer AND if the window is currently visible (not hidden)
		return win_buf == state.buf and vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(win_id, "winblend") == 0
	end
	return false
end

-- Helper to hide our terminal in a given window
local function hide_our_terminal(win_id)
	if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_id) then
		local win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_id)
		if win_buf == state.buf then
			vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_id)
		end
	end
end

local function open_terminal(mode)
	local target_win_id = state[mode].win
	local opened_win_id = nil

	-- Determine if the target terminal mode is already visible and active
	if is_our_terminal_visible(target_win_id) then
		-- If it's already visible, then we are in a "toggle off" state for this mode.
		-- Just hide it and return.
		hide_our_terminal(target_win_id)
		return
	end

	-- If we're here, the target terminal is either not valid, or valid but hidden.
	-- First, hide all *other* terminal windows that might be currently visible.
	-- We want only one instance of our shared terminal to be visible at a time.
	for _, mode_key in ipairs({ "floating", "vertical", "horizontal" }) do
		if mode_key ~= mode then -- Don't hide the one we are about to open/show
			hide_our_terminal(state[mode_key].win)
		end
	end

	-- Now, either create the window or show the existing one
	if not vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(target_win_id) then
		if mode == "floating" then
			opened_win_id = create_floating_window()
		else
			opened_win_id = create_split_window(mode)
		end
	else
		-- Window is valid but hidden (or was previously used by something else)
		vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(target_win_id, set_shared_buffer()) -- Ensure it shows our buffer
		vim.api.nvim_win_show(target_win_id) -- Make it visible
		opened_win_id = target_win_id
	end

	-- Ensure the buffer is a terminal buffer
	local current_buf = set_shared_buffer()
	if vim.bo[current_buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
		vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Ensure correct window is active for :terminal
		vim.cmd("terminal")
	end

	vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
	state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

-- Commands for each terminal layout
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("FT", function()
	open_terminal("floating")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("HT", function()
	open_terminal("horizontal")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("VT", function()
	open_terminal("vertical")
end, {})

-- Toggle command
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("TT", function()
	local target_mode = state.last_mode or "floating" -- Default to floating
	open_terminal(target_mode)
end, {})

return {}

local state = {
    buf = -1, -- The one and only shared terminal buffer
    floating = { win = -1 },
    vertical = { win = -1 },
    horizontal = { win = -1 },
    last_mode = nil,
}

-- This function now correctly ensures the shared buffer exists
local function set_shared_buffer()
    if not vim.api.nvim_buf_is_valid(state.buf) then
        state.buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true) -- Create if it doesn't exist
    end
    return state.buf
end

local function create_floating_window(opts)
    opts = opts or {}
    local width = opts.width or math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.75)
    local height = opts.height or math.floor(vim.o.lines * 0.75)

    local col = math.floor((vim.o.columns - width) / 2)
    local row = math.floor((vim.o.lines - height) / 2)

    local buf = set_shared_buffer() -- Use the shared buffer

    local win_config = {
        relative = "editor",
        width = width,
        height = height,
        col = col,
        row = row,
        style = "minimal",
        border = "rounded",
    }

    local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, win_config)
    state.floating.win = win -- Store the created window ID
    return win -- Return the window ID directly
end

local function create_split_window(orientation)
    local cmd = orientation == "vertical" and "vsplit" or "split"
    vim.cmd(cmd) -- This creates a new window displaying the *current* buffer initially

    local buf = set_shared_buffer() -- Use the shared buffer
    vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(0, buf) -- Set the new split to display the shared buffer

    if orientation == "horizontal" then
        vim.cmd("resize 10")
    end

    local win = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
    state[orientation].win = win -- Store the created window ID
    return win
end

-- Helper to check if our shared terminal is active in a given window
local function is_our_terminal_visible(win_id)
    if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_id) then
        local win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_id)
        -- Check if it's our shared buffer AND if the window is currently visible (not hidden)
        return win_buf == state.buf and vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(win_id, "winblend") == 0
    end
    return false
end

-- Helper to hide our terminal in a given window
local function hide_our_terminal(win_id)
    if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_id) then
        local win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_id)
        if win_buf == state.buf then
            vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_id)
        end
    end
end


local function open_terminal(mode)
    local target_win_id = state[mode].win
    local opened_win_id = nil

    -- Determine if the target terminal mode is already visible and active
    if is_our_terminal_visible(target_win_id) then
        -- If it's already visible, then we are in a "toggle off" state for this mode.
        -- Just hide it and return.
        hide_our_terminal(target_win_id)
        return
    end

    -- If we're here, the target terminal is either not valid, or valid but hidden.
    -- First, hide all *other* terminal windows that might be currently visible.
    -- We want only one instance of our shared terminal to be visible at a time.
    for _, mode_key in ipairs({"floating", "vertical", "horizontal"}) do
        if mode_key ~= mode then -- Don't hide the one we are about to open/show
            hide_our_terminal(state[mode_key].win)
        end
    end

    -- Now, either create the window or show the existing one
    if not vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(target_win_id) then
        if mode == "floating" then
            opened_win_id = create_floating_window()
        else
            opened_win_id = create_split_window(mode)
        end
    else
        -- Window is valid but hidden (or was previously used by something else)
        vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(target_win_id, set_shared_buffer()) -- Ensure it shows our buffer
        vim.api.nvim_win_show(target_win_id) -- Make it visible
        opened_win_id = target_win_id
    end

    -- Ensure the buffer is a terminal buffer
    local current_buf = set_shared_buffer()
    if vim.bo[current_buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
        vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Ensure correct window is active for :terminal
        vim.cmd("terminal")
    end

    vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
    state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

-- Commands for each terminal layout
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("FT", function()
    open_terminal("floating")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("HT", function()
    open_terminal("horizontal")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("VT", function()
    open_terminal("vertical")
end, {})

-- Toggle command
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("TT", function()
    local target_mode = state.last_mode or "floating" -- Default to floating
    open_terminal(target_mode)
end, {})

return {}

local state = {
	buf = -1, -- Shared terminal buffer
	floating = { win = -1 },
	vertical = { win = -1 },
	horizontal = { win = -1 },
	last_mode = "floating", -- Added to store the last opened mode
}

local function set_buffer()
	if vim.api.nvim_buf_is_valid(state.buf) then
		return state.buf
	end
	local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true) -- scratch buffer
	state.buf = buf
	return buf
end

local function create_floating_window(opts)
	opts = opts or {}
	local width = opts.width or math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.75)
	local height = opts.height or math.floor(vim.o.lines * 0.75)

	-- Calculate the position to center the window
	local col = math.floor((vim.o.columns - width) / 2)
	local row = math.floor((vim.o.lines - height) / 2)

	-- Create or set the buffer
	local buf = set_buffer()

	-- Define window configuration
	local win_config = {
		relative = "editor",
		width = width,
		height = height,
		col = col,
		row = row,
		style = "minimal", -- No borders or extra UI elements
		border = "rounded",
	}

	-- Create the floating window
	local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, win_config)

	return { buf = buf, win = win }
end

local function create_split_window(orientation)
	local cmd = orientation == "vertical" and "vsplit" or "split"
	vim.cmd(cmd)

	local buf = set_buffer()
	vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(0, buf)

	if orientation == "horizontal" then
		vim.cmd("resize 10")
	end

	local win = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
	state[orientation].win = win

	return win
end

local function open_terminal(mode)
	local target = state[mode]

	-- If we reach here, either the window was not valid or we are opening a new one
	-- or switching modes.
	-- First, hide any currently active terminal window if it's ours.
	for _, mode_key in ipairs({ "floating", "vertical", "horizontal" }) do
		local win_to_hide = state[mode_key].win
		if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_to_hide) then
			local buf_of_win = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_to_hide)
			if buf_of_win == state.buf then
				vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_to_hide)
			end
		end
	end

	local opened_win_id
	if mode == "floating" then
		local float_data = create_floating_window()
		opened_win_id = float_data.win
		-- Also update the state for floating window
		state.floating.win = opened_win_id
	else
		-- create_split_window already sets state[mode].win internally
		opened_win_id = create_split_window(mode)
	end

	-- Set the buffer to terminal type if it's not already
	if vim.bo[state.buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
		vim.cmd("terminal")
	end

	-- Corrected line:
	vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
	state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

-- Commands for each terminal layout
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("FT", function()
	open_terminal("floating")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("HT", function()
	open_terminal("horizontal")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("VT", function()
	open_terminal("vertical")
end, {})

-- New toggle command
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("TT", function()
	if state.last_mode and vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(state[state.last_mode].win) then
		-- If there's a last mode and its window is valid, toggle it
		local target = state[state.last_mode]
		local current_win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(target.win)
		if current_win_buf == state.buf then
			if vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(target.win, "winblend") == 0 then
				vim.api.nvim_win_hide(target.win)
			else
				vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(target.win)
			end
		else
			-- If the buffer in the last_mode window isn't our terminal buffer,
			-- it means the window was reused by something else.
			-- So, open the terminal in the last_mode.
			open_terminal(state.last_mode)
		end
	elseif state.last_mode then
		-- If last_mode exists but the window isn't valid, re-open it
		open_terminal(state.last_mode)
	else
		-- If no last mode is set, default to floating
		open_terminal("floating")
	end
end, {})

return {}

local state = {
	buf = -1, -- Shared terminal buffer
	floating = { win = -1 },
	vertical = { win = -1 },
	horizontal = { win = -1 },
	last_mode = "floating", -- Added to store the last opened mode
}

local function set_buffer()
	if vim.api.nvim_buf_is_valid(state.buf) then
		return state.buf
	end
	local buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true) -- scratch buffer
	state.buf = buf
	return buf
end

local function create_floating_window(opts)
	opts = opts or {}
	local width = opts.width or math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.75)
	local height = opts.height or math.floor(vim.o.lines * 0.75)

	-- Calculate the position to center the window
	local col = math.floor((vim.o.columns - width) / 2)
	local row = math.floor((vim.o.lines - height) / 2)

	-- Create or set the buffer
	local buf = set_buffer()

	-- Define window configuration
	local win_config = {
		relative = "editor",
		width = width,
		height = height,
		col = col,
		row = row,
		style = "minimal", -- No borders or extra UI elements
		border = "rounded",
	}

	-- Create the floating window
	local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, win_config)

	return { buf = buf, win = win }
end

local function create_split_window(orientation)
	local cmd = orientation == "vertical" and "vsplit" or "split"
	vim.cmd(cmd)

	local buf = set_buffer()
	vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(0, buf)

	if orientation == "horizontal" then
		vim.cmd("resize 10")
	end

	local win = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
	state[orientation].win = win

	return win
end

local function open_terminal(mode)
	local target = state[mode]

	-- If we reach here, either the window was not valid or we are opening a new one
	-- or switching modes.
	-- First, hide any currently active terminal window if it's ours.
	for _, mode_key in ipairs({ "floating", "vertical", "horizontal" }) do
		local win_to_hide = state[mode_key].win
		if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_to_hide) then
			local buf_of_win = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_to_hide)
			if buf_of_win == state.buf then
				vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_to_hide)
			end
		end
	end

	local opened_win_id
	if mode == "floating" then
		local float_data = create_floating_window()
		opened_win_id = float_data.win
		-- Also update the state for floating window
		state.floating.win = opened_win_id
	else
		-- create_split_window already sets state[mode].win internally
		opened_win_id = create_split_window(mode)
	end

	-- Set the buffer to terminal type if it's not already
	if vim.bo[state.buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
		vim.cmd("terminal")
	end

	-- Corrected line:
	vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
	state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

-- Commands for each terminal layout
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("FT", function()
	open_terminal("floating")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("HT", function()
	open_terminal("horizontal")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("VT", function()
	open_terminal("vertical")
end, {})

-- New toggle command
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("TT", function()
	if state.last_mode and vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(state[state.last_mode].win) then
		-- If there's a last mode and its window is valid, toggle it
		local target = state[state.last_mode]
		local current_win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(target.win)
		if current_win_buf == state.buf then
			if vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(target.win, "winblend") == 0 then
				vim.api.nvim_win_hide(target.win)
			else
				vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(target.win)
			end
		else
			-- If the buffer in the last_mode window isn't our terminal buffer,
			-- it means the window was reused by something else.
			-- So, open the terminal in the last_mode.
			open_terminal(state.last_mode)
		end
	elseif state.last_mode then
		-- If last_mode exists but the window isn't valid, re-open it
		open_terminal(state.last_mode)
	else
		-- If no last mode is set, default to floating
		open_terminal("floating")
	end
end, {})

local function open_terminal(mode)
    local target = state[mode]

    -- If we reach here, either the window was not valid or we are opening a new one
    -- or switching modes.
    -- First, hide any currently active terminal window if it's ours.
    for _, mode_key in ipairs({"floating", "vertical", "horizontal"}) do
        local win_to_hide = state[mode_key].win
        if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_to_hide) then
            local buf_of_win = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_to_hide)
            if buf_of_win == state.buf then
                vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_to_hide)
            end
        end
    end

    local opened_win_id
    if mode == "floating" then
        local float_data = create_floating_window()
        opened_win_id = float_data.win
        -- Also update the state for floating window
        state.floating.win = opened_win_id
    else
        -- create_split_window already sets state[mode].win internally
        opened_win_id = create_split_window(mode)
    end

    -- Set the buffer to terminal type if it's not already
    if vim.bo[state.buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
        vim.cmd("terminal")
    end

    -- Corrected line:
    vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(opened_win_id) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
    state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

local function create_floating_window(opts)
    opts = opts or {}
    local width = opts.width or math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.75)
    local height = opts.height or math.floor(vim.o.lines * 0.75)

    -- Calculate the position to center the window
    local col = math.floor((vim.o.columns - width) / 2)
    local row = math.floor((vim.o.lines - height) / 2)

    -- Create or set the buffer
    local buf = set_buffer()

    -- Define window configuration
    local win_config = {
        relative = "editor",
        width = width,
        height = height,
        col = col,
        row = row,
        style = "minimal", -- No borders or extra UI elements
        border = "rounded",
    }

    -- Create the floating window
    local win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, win_config)

    return { buf = buf, win = win }
end

local function create_split_window(orientation)
    local cmd = orientation == "vertical" and "vsplit" or "split"
    vim.cmd(cmd)

    local buf = set_buffer()
    vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(0, buf)

    if orientation == "horizontal" then
        vim.cmd("resize 10")
    end

    local win = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
    state[orientation].win = win

    return win
end

local function open_terminal(mode)
    local target = state[mode]

    -- Check if the target window for the current mode is valid
    if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(target.win) then
        -- If it's valid, it means the terminal for this mode is already open.
        -- We want to hide it if it's currently visible.
        -- This logic is tricky if you want to ensure it's the *only* visible one.
        -- For a simple toggle, if it's open, hide it. If it's hidden, show it.
        local current_win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(target.win)
        if current_win_buf == state.buf then -- Ensure it's *our* terminal buffer
            if vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(target.win, "winblend") == 0 then -- Check if visible (winblend is 0 for non-floating, or active floating)
                vim.api.nvim_win_hide(target.win)
            else
                vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(target.win)
            end
            return -- Exit after toggling visibility
        end
    end

    -- If we reach here, either the window was not valid or we are opening a new one
    -- or switching modes.
    -- First, hide any currently active terminal window if it's ours.
    for _, mode_key in ipairs({"floating", "vertical", "horizontal"}) do
        local win_to_hide = state[mode_key].win
        if vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_to_hide) then
            local buf_of_win = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(win_to_hide)
            if buf_of_win == state.buf then
                vim.api.nvim_win_hide(win_to_hide)
            end
        end
    end

    local win
    if mode == "floating" then
        win = create_floating_window()
    else
        win = create_split_window(mode)
    end

    -- Set the buffer to terminal type if it's not already
    if vim.bo[state.buf].buftype ~= "terminal" then
        vim.cmd("terminal")
    end

    vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(win.win or win) -- Make the newly opened/shown window active
    state.last_mode = mode -- Update the last used mode
end

-- Commands for each terminal layout
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("FT", function()
    open_terminal("floating")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("HT", function()
    open_terminal("horizontal")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("VT", function()
    open_terminal("vertical")
end, {})

-- New toggle command
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("TT", function()
    if state.last_mode and vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(state[state.last_mode].win) then
        -- If there's a last mode and its window is valid, toggle it
        local target = state[state.last_mode]
        local current_win_buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(target.win)
        if current_win_buf == state.buf then
            if vim.api.nvim_win_get_option(target.win, "winblend") == 0 then
                vim.api.nvim_win_hide(target.win)
            else
                vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(target.win)
            end
        else
            -- If the buffer in the last_mode window isn't our terminal buffer,
            -- it means the window was reused by something else.
            -- So, open the terminal in the last_mode.
            open_terminal(state.last_mode)
        end
    elseif state.last_mode then
        -- If last_mode exists but the window isn't valid, re-open it
        open_terminal(state.last_mode)
    else
        -- If no last mode is set, default to floating
        open_terminal("floating")
    end
end, {})

---
## Debunking ATS Myths for a Human-Centric Resume

Many job seekers believe that Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) are sophisticated AI tools that automatically reject resumes based on keyword matching or compliance scores. However, this is a misconception. ATS platforms are primarily databases designed to store and organize applications, not to act as "terminators" that filter out candidates. The real challenge for job seekers isn't bypassing an AI, but rather making their resume clear and impactful enough to capture a human recruiter's attention in a short amount of time.

---
### Key Myths About ATS and Resumes:

* **Myth 1: ATS automatically rejects resumes for missing keywords or low scores.**
    * **Reality:** ATS systems don't have a "rejection algorithm" or a scoring system that filters out candidates based on keyword density or percentage matches. Third-party sites often invent these metrics to sell their services. Recruiters rarely use clunky keyword filters as they often yield irrelevant results. The absence of a callback is due to the resume not clearly conveying value to a human reader, not an automated rejection.
    * **Action:** Focus on **clarity** over keyword stuffing. Naturally embed relevant job titles and core skills from the posting into your achievements and bullet points. Write for a human reader, not a robot.

* **Myth 2: You need an "ATS-compliant" resume.**
    * **Reality:** There's no such thing as an "ATS-compliant" resume score. These scores are generated by third-party tools, not by the ATS itself, and are not seen or used by recruiters. Chasing these fake scores can lead to diluted messaging and a less effective resume.
    * **Action:** Aim for a **"reader-compliant"** resume. Use a clean, standard layout, avoid graphics or gimmicks, and ensure your strongest achievements are immediately visible. Clarity is key to getting interviews, not a manufactured score.

* **Myth 3: The "white font trick" works to hide keywords.**
    * **Reality:** This is an outdated and counterproductive tactic. When a resume is parsed by an ATS, all text, including white font, is extracted into plain text. Recruiters will see these hidden keywords, which makes you appear untrustworthy and attempting to game the system.
    * **Action:** **Highlight** relevant skills naturally within your experience and achievements. Show how you've applied a skill with concrete examples and results, rather than just listing it.

* **Myth 4: ATS systems use AI to screen candidates.**
    * **Reality:** Most ATS platforms are older, legacy systems not equipped with advanced AI for making hiring decisions. Furthermore, legal compliance issues (like OFCCP and EEOC regulations) prohibit companies from using automated tools to make final hiring decisions; human review is required by law. Recruiters make decisions, not algorithms.
    * **Action:** **Write for a person, not a platform.** Structure your resume to quickly convey your relevance and results. Lead with impact, use scannable language, and make your contributions obvious.

* **Myth 5: Getting rejected means the system filtered you out.**
    * **Reality:** Silence after applying typically means a human recruiter overlooked your application due to high volume or a lack of immediate clarity in your resume. It's not a rejection by a bot, but invisibility to a human with limited time. Automated rejections are usually due to "knockout questions" set by recruiters (e.g., "Do you require visa sponsorship?").
    * **Action:** **Optimize for human attention.** Make your value clear in the first few lines by leading with results. Use formatting that allows for quick scanning. Focus on effectively selling your skills and story to a human audience.

---
### What Actually Works: A Recruiter-Approved Framework

The goal of your resume is to get seen, read, and remembered by a human. This hinges on clarity and impact.

1.  **Write for the Reader, Not the System:** Recruiters skim hundreds of resumes quickly. Lead with your best accomplishments and ensure your most recent job title is immediately obvious. Use a clean, easily scscannable layout.
2.  **Show Business Impact, Not Just Job Activity:** Instead of listing duties, highlight the **outcomes** of your work with specific numbers and results (e.g., "reduced churn by 14%", "increased pipeline conversions by 22%").
3.  **Bridge the Title Gap:** If your current job title doesn't perfectly match the role you're applying for, provide context. Use parentheses or a one-line summary to explain how your experience translates directly to the target role.

By understanding that your audience is human, you can stop wasting time on non-existent ATS filters and instead focus on crafting a resume that clearly communicates your value and gets you noticed.

---
## Prompt for LLMs to Create a Resume:

Based on the understanding that resumes are primarily read by humans and that ATS systems are mainly for tracking, not filtering, create a resume that prioritizes clarity, impact, and human readability.

Here's the framework to follow:

**Resume Objective/Summary (Optional but Recommended for Career Changers):**
* If included, make it concise (1-2 sentences) and immediately highlight your most relevant qualifications and the value you bring to the target role.

**Contact Information:**
* Standard format: Name, Phone, Email, LinkedIn Profile URL.

**Professional Experience:**
* For each role, clearly state: **Job Title, Company Name, Location, Dates of Employment.**
* **Prioritize business impact over job duties.** For each bullet point, quantify your achievements with specific numbers, percentages, or concrete examples. Focus on *what changed because of your actions*.
    * **Example (Instead of "Managed projects"):** "Led cross-functional team of 8+ to deliver new product features 2 weeks ahead of schedule."
    * **Example (Instead of "Oversaw internal communications"):** "Streamlined internal communication processes, reducing meeting time by 15% and increasing team collaboration scores by 10%."
* If there's a **"title gap"** (your current title doesn't directly match the target role), add a concise clarifier in parentheses next to your job title to connect your experience to the desired position.
    * **Example:** "Product Manager (Functionally led roadmap without formal title)"

**Education:**
* Degree, Major, University Name, Location, Graduation Date (or expected date).
* Relevant coursework or honors can be included if space permits and they are highly relevant.

**Skills:**
* List relevant technical skills, software proficiency, languages, etc. Be specific.

**Formatting and Layout Considerations:**
* **Clarity and Scannability are Paramount:** Use a clean, standard, and easy-to-read layout.
* **Standard Fonts:** Stick to professional, widely available fonts (e.g., Arial, Calibri, Times New Roman).
* **Avoid Gimmicks:** No graphics, images, or overly complex templates that might disrupt readability for a human or parsing by an ATS.
* **Conciseness:** Aim for 1-2 pages, depending on years of experience, ensuring every element adds value and is easy to skim.
* **Active Voice:** Use strong action verbs at the start of your bullet points.

**Overall Goal:**
The resume should be designed so that a human recruiter can **skim it in 5-7 seconds** and immediately understand:
1.  What your core qualifications are.
2.  The business impact you've created.
3.  Why you are a strong fit for the specific role.

Please provide the job description or details about the type of role you're applying for so I can tailor the resume effectively. What specific achievements or experiences do you want to highlight?

TRIOS COLLEGE, Network Administrator	20XX
man git-commit | col -bx | grep -A 10000 -- "--amend" | grep -B 1 -- "--amend" | sed -n '/--amend/,/^       --[^ ]/p'

--amend
           Replace the tip of the current branch by creating a new commit. The
           recorded tree is prepared as usual (including the effect of the -i
           and -o options and explicit pathspec), and the message from the
           original commit is used as the starting point, instead of an empty
           message, when no other message is specified from the command line
           via options such as -m, -F, -c, etc. The new commit has the same
           parents and author as the current one (the --reset-author option
           can countermand this).

           It is a rough equivalent for:

                       $ git reset --soft HEAD^
                       $ ... do something else to come up with the right tree ...
                       $ git commit -c ORIG_HEAD

           but can be used to amend a merge commit.

           You should understand the implications of rewriting history if you
           amend a commit that has already been published. (See the
           "RECOVERING FROM UPSTREAM REBASE" section in git-rebase(1).)
